column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#Text=[0040] A stable spherical vaterite calcium carbonate material was prepared in accordance with the present invention as follows.
#Text=First, 4 liters of 2 M reagent grade sodium carbonate was added to a rotor-stator, high speed dispersion Kady.RTM. lab mill (model number L) available from Kady International, Scarborough, Me.
#Text=Next, 4 liters of 2 M reagent grade calcium chloride was poured into the sodium carbonate solution.
#Text=The mixture was stirred with the Kady mill at 40 Hz for five minutes.
#Text=The reaction was carried out at room temperature (25.degree.
#Text=C.).
#Text=To the resultant vaterite slurry was added 1.4 g of sodium polyphosphate, (NaPO3).sub.n available from Aldrich Chemical Company.
#Text=The slurry was placed in a 5-gal. plastic bucket.
#Text=Three more batches of vaterite were prepared as described above and the slurries were all combined in the bucket.
#Text=Thereafter, the combined slurry was filtered on a buchner funnel and washed with deionized water.
#Text=The filter cake was dried in an oven at 100.degree.
#Text=C. overnight.
#Text=Physical properties of Example 1 stabilized vaterite is given in Table 1 below.
#Text=EXAMPLE 2
#Text=[0041] A stable vaterite calcium carbonate was prepared by first preparing a solution of 2 molar calcium chloride and 4 molar monoethanolamine.

#Text=This solution was stored for 2 weeks before use. 6 liters of the previously prepared calcium chloride/monoethanolamine solution was added to a 5-gal reactor equipped with mechanical stirring means.
#Text=The pH of this solution was 11.1.
#Text=Carbon dioxide gas was added to the stirred reactor contents at a rate of 22.5 L/min.
#Text=Carbonation continued until the reaction mixture reached pH 7.46, which took about 34 minutes.
#Text=Carbonation and stirring was stopped for 30 minutes.
#Text=Thereafter, carbonation and stirring resumed until the reaction slurry reached pH 6.87.

#Text=The resultant vaterite slurry was filtered and washed with deionized water until the filtrate slurry reached a conductivity of 500 .mu.S, indicating the by-product salt had been washed from the wet cake.
#Text=The vaterite wet cake was stabilized by mixing 12 g of sodium polyphosphate into the wet cake.
#Text=Thereafter, the resultant stabilized vaterite was dried overnight in an oven at 100.degree.
#Text=C.
#Text=Physical properties of Example 2 are given in Table 1 below.
#Text=COMPARATIVE EXAMPLE 3

#Text=[0042] The procedure of Example 2 was followed, except the solution of 2 M calcium chloride--4 M monoethanolamine was prepared, filtered to remove trace insoluble material, then used without ageing.
#Text=Physical properties of Comparative Example 3 are given in Table 1 below.
